trans-unit.source: Get started configuring your Internet-facing load balancer
trans-unit.target: Get started configuring your Internet-facing load balancer

trans-unit.source: Load balancing services in Microsoft Azure work with all the tenant types (IaaS or PaaS) and all supported operating systems (Windows or any supported Linux-based operating system).
trans-unit.target: Load balancing services in Microsoft Azure work with all the tenant types (IaaS or PaaS) and all supported operating systems (Windows or any supported Linux-based operating system).

trans-unit.source: Set up an Internet-facing load balancer for virtual machines
trans-unit.target: Set up an Internet-facing load balancer for virtual machines

trans-unit.source: In order to load balance network traffic from the Internet across the virtual machines of a cloud service, you must create a load-balanced set.
trans-unit.target: In order to load balance network traffic from the Internet across the virtual machines of a cloud service, you must create a load-balanced set.

trans-unit.source: This procedure assumes that you have already created the virtual machines and that they are all within the same cloud service.
trans-unit.target: This procedure assumes that you have already created the virtual machines and that they are all within the same cloud service.

trans-unit.source: To configure a load-balanced set for virtual machines
trans-unit.target: To configure a load-balanced set for virtual machines

trans-unit.source: In the Azure portal, click Virtual Machines, and then click the name of a virtual machine in the load-balanced set.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure portal, click Virtual Machines, and then click the name of a virtual machine in the load-balanced set.

trans-unit.source: Click Endpoints, and then click Add.
trans-unit.target: Click Endpoints, and then click Add.

trans-unit.source: On the Add an endpoint to a virtual machine page, click the right arrow.
trans-unit.target: On the Add an endpoint to a virtual machine page, click the right arrow.

trans-unit.source: On the Specify the details of the endpoint page:
trans-unit.target: On the Specify the details of the endpoint page:

trans-unit.source: In Name, type a name for the endpoint or select the name from the list of predefined endpoints for common protocols.
trans-unit.target: In Name, type a name for the endpoint or select the name from the list of predefined endpoints for common protocols.

trans-unit.source: In Protocol, select the protocol required by the type of endpoint, either TCP or UDP, as needed.
trans-unit.target: In Protocol, select the protocol required by the type of endpoint, either TCP or UDP, as needed.

trans-unit.source: In Public Port and Private Port, type the port numbers that you want the virtual machine to use, as needed.
trans-unit.target: In Public Port and Private Port, type the port numbers that you want the virtual machine to use, as needed.

trans-unit.source: You can use the private port and firewall rules on the virtual machine to redirect traffic in a way that is appropriate for your application.
trans-unit.target: You can use the private port and firewall rules on the virtual machine to redirect traffic in a way that is appropriate for your application.

trans-unit.source: The private port can be the same as the public port.
trans-unit.target: The private port can be the same as the public port.

trans-unit.source: For example, for an endpoint for web (HTTP) traffic, you could assign port 80 to both the public and private port.
trans-unit.target: For example, for an endpoint for web (HTTP) traffic, you could assign port 80 to both the public and private port.

trans-unit.source: Select Create a load-balanced set, and then click the right arrow.
trans-unit.target: Select Create a load-balanced set, and then click the right arrow.

trans-unit.source: On the Configure the load-balanced set page, type a name for the load-balanced set, and then assign the values for probe behavior of the Azure Load Balancer.
trans-unit.target: On the Configure the load-balanced set page, type a name for the load-balanced set, and then assign the values for probe behavior of the Azure Load Balancer.

trans-unit.source: The Load Balancer uses probes to determine if the virtual machines in the load-balanced set are available to receive incoming traffic.
trans-unit.target: The Load Balancer uses probes to determine if the virtual machines in the load-balanced set are available to receive incoming traffic.

trans-unit.source: Click the check mark to create the load-balanced endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Click the check mark to create the load-balanced endpoint.

trans-unit.source: You will see Yes in the Load-balanced set name column of the Endpoints page for the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: You will see Yes in the Load-balanced set name column of the Endpoints page for the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: In the portal, click Virtual Machines, click the name of an additional virtual machine in the load-balanced set, click Endpoints, and then click Add.
trans-unit.target: In the portal, click Virtual Machines, click the name of an additional virtual machine in the load-balanced set, click Endpoints, and then click Add.

trans-unit.source: On the Add an endpoint to a virtual machine page, click Add endpoint to an existing load-balanced set, select the name of the load-balanced set, and then click the right arrow.
trans-unit.target: On the Add an endpoint to a virtual machine page, click Add endpoint to an existing load-balanced set, select the name of the load-balanced set, and then click the right arrow.

trans-unit.source: On the Specify the details of the endpoint page, type a name for the endpoint, and then click the check mark.
trans-unit.target: On the Specify the details of the endpoint page, type a name for the endpoint, and then click the check mark.

trans-unit.source: For the additional virtual machines in the load-balanced set, repeat steps 8-10.
trans-unit.target: For the additional virtual machines in the load-balanced set, repeat steps 8-10.

trans-unit.source: You can also configure endpoints with the following Windows PowerShell cmdlets:
trans-unit.target: You can also configure endpoints with the following Windows PowerShell cmdlets:

trans-unit.source: Add-AzureEndpoint
trans-unit.target: Add-AzureEndpoint

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Add-AzureEndpoint</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Add-AzureEndpoint</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Get-AzureEndpoint
trans-unit.target: Get-AzureEndpoint

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Get-AzureEndpoint</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Get-AzureEndpoint</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Remove-AzureEndpoint
trans-unit.target: Remove-AzureEndpoint

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Remove-AzureEndpoint</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Remove-AzureEndpoint</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Set up an Internet-facing load balancer for cloud services
trans-unit.target: Set up an Internet-facing load balancer for cloud services

trans-unit.source: Cloud services are automatically configured with a load balancer and can be customized via the service model.
trans-unit.target: Cloud services are automatically configured with a load balancer and can be customized via the service model.

trans-unit.source: You can leverage the Azure SDK for .NET 2.5 to update your cloud service.
trans-unit.target: You can leverage the Azure SDK for .NET 2.5 to update your cloud service.

trans-unit.source: Endpoint settings for cloud services are made in the <link><linkText>service definition</linkText><title></title></link>.csdef file.
trans-unit.target: Endpoint settings for cloud services are made in the <link><linkText>service definition</linkText><title></title></link>.csdef file.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how a servicedefinition.csdef file for a cloud deployment is configured:
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how a servicedefinition.csdef file for a cloud deployment is configured:

trans-unit.source: Checking the snipet for the .csdef file generated by a cloud deployment, you can see the external endpoint configured to use ports HTTP on port 10000, 10001, and 10002.
trans-unit.target: Checking the snipet for the .csdef file generated by a cloud deployment, you can see the external endpoint configured to use ports HTTP on port 10000, 10001, and 10002.

trans-unit.source: Check load balancer health status for cloud services
trans-unit.target: Check load balancer health status for cloud services

trans-unit.source: The following is an example of a health probe:
trans-unit.target: The following is an example of a health probe:

trans-unit.source: The load balancer combines the information of the endpoint and the information of the probe to create a URL in the form of http://{DIP of VM}:80/Probe.aspx that can be used to query the health of the service.
trans-unit.target: The load balancer combines the information of the endpoint and the information of the probe to create a URL in the form of http://{DIP of VM}:80/Probe.aspx that can be used to query the health of the service.

trans-unit.source: The service detects periodic probes from the same IP address.
trans-unit.target: The service detects periodic probes from the same IP address.

trans-unit.source: This is the health probe request coming from the host of the node where the virtual machine is running.
trans-unit.target: This is the health probe request coming from the host of the node where the virtual machine is running.

trans-unit.source: The service has to respond with a HTTP 200 status code for the load balancer to assume that the service is healthy.
trans-unit.target: The service has to respond with a HTTP 200 status code for the load balancer to assume that the service is healthy.

trans-unit.source: Any other HTTP status code (for example 503) directly takes the virtual machine out of rotation.
trans-unit.target: Any other HTTP status code (for example 503) directly takes the virtual machine out of rotation.

trans-unit.source: The probe definition also controls the frequency of the probe.
trans-unit.target: The probe definition also controls the frequency of the probe.

trans-unit.source: In our case above, the load balancer is probing the endpoint every 5 secs.
trans-unit.target: In our case above, the load balancer is probing the endpoint every 5 secs.

trans-unit.source: If no positive answer is received for 10 secs (two probe intervals), the probe is assumed down, and the virtual machine is taken out of rotation.
trans-unit.target: If no positive answer is received for 10 secs (two probe intervals), the probe is assumed down, and the virtual machine is taken out of rotation.

trans-unit.source: Similarly, if the service is out of rotation and a positive answer is received, the service is put back to rotation right away.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, if the service is out of rotation and a positive answer is received, the service is put back to rotation right away.

trans-unit.source: If the service is fluctuating between healthy and unhealthy, the load balancer can decide to delay the re-introduction of the service back to rotation until it has been healthy for a number of probes.
trans-unit.target: If the service is fluctuating between healthy and unhealthy, the load balancer can decide to delay the re-introduction of the service back to rotation until it has been healthy for a number of probes.

trans-unit.source: Check the service definition schema for the <link><linkText>health probe</linkText><title></title></link> for more information.
trans-unit.target: Check the service definition schema for the <link><linkText>health probe</linkText><title></title></link> for more information.

trans-unit.source: Set up load balancer using PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Set up load balancer using PowerShell

trans-unit.source: After creating a virtual machine, you can use PowerShell cmdlets to add a load balancer to a virtual machine within the same cloud service.
trans-unit.target: After creating a virtual machine, you can use PowerShell cmdlets to add a load balancer to a virtual machine within the same cloud service.

trans-unit.source: In the example below, you will add a load balancer called "webfarm" to cloud service endpoint "mycloudservice" (or mycloudservice.cloudapp.net) and a virtual machine named myVM.
trans-unit.target: In the example below, you will add a load balancer called "webfarm" to cloud service endpoint "mycloudservice" (or mycloudservice.cloudapp.net) and a virtual machine named myVM.

trans-unit.source: The load balancer receives traffic on port 80 and load balances the network traffic between the virtual machines on port 8080 using HTTP.
trans-unit.target: The load balancer receives traffic on port 80 and load balances the network traffic between the virtual machines on port 8080 using HTTP.
